Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for the 59th Session of the International Statistical Institute, Hong Kong
Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Statistical Association (ASA) will use this NSF award as a travel grant for approximately 10 United States participants to attend the 59th Session of the International Statistical Institute (ISI) in Hong Kong from August 25-30, 2013. The ISI meeting includes the meetings of the Bernoulli Society, International Association for Official Statistics (IAOS), International Association for Statistical Computing (IASC), International Association of Survey Statisticians (IASS), and the International Association for Statistical Education (IASE). Thus it is an umbrella meeting with sessions of interest for thousands of statisticians. The travel grants will provide support to defray transportation costs for individuals selected from institutions and non-profit associations. An emphasis of the award is to encourage and provide the opportunity for younger statisticians to participate in the meeting.

Participants will be notified of the availability of the travel grant through Amstat News, a membership publication of the ASA, and on the ASA Home Page on the Internet. Notices will be provided to university and college statistics and mathematics departments to encourage younger statisticians to apply for the travel grant. A review and selection committee will be established to review the applications and select grantees. The committee will be comprised of three or more ASA members and will convene at the ASA office in Alexandria, Virginia. Special consideration will be given to statisticians who have recently received their Ph.D.'s and to women and minorities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funding for ten recipients to attend the 59th Session of the International Statistical Institute (ISI) held in Hong Kong from August 25-30, 2013. Special emphasis was placed on newer faculty (those who have completed Ph.D. requirements in 2004 or later), women, and minorities to apply and receive funding. 

The ISI is an international professional society whose membership is drawn from individual scientists, national statistical offices and their representatives, and national professional associations.  It was established in 1885 and now has eight sections:  (1) the Bernoulli Society for Mathematical Statistics and Probability, (2) the International Association of Survey Statisticians (IASS), (3) the International Association for Statistical Computing (IASC), (4) the International Association for Official Statistics (IAOS), (5) the International Association for Statistical Education (IASE), (6) the Irving Fisher Committee on Central Bank Statistics (IFC), (7) the International Environmetrics Society (TIES), (8) and the International Society for Business and Industrial Statistics (ISBIS). 

During the 59th Session of the ISI, several sections held meetings, not only within the general program, but also as independent "satellite" meetings from all parts of the world.  These smaller, more focused meetings brought
together experts in numerous fields throughout the world, as well as many
younger researchers from Ireland who had a unique opportunity to meet, converse with, and discuss specific programs with the outstanding experts in the particular areas. The Session also attracted a significant number of statisticians from the developing and less-developed countries as well as a large number of government statisticians. The session’s topics reflect this attendance, as exemplified by a “Youth Theme Day” in which many sessions related to youth issues around the world. This was also the first year that virtual participation was available. 

The 59th WSC provided a platform for the international statistical community to share and present the latest knowledge and innovation in statistics. The scientific program encompassed a wide range of topics facilitating professional exchanges and sharing amongst experts and practitioners in various statistical spheres. Featuring the unique theme "Youth", a series of sessions was organized on the "Theme Day" of the 59th WSC to address, from various statistical perspectives, topics surrounding the "Youth". Delegates were welcomed to plan tailor-made events from a wide spectrum of activities including scientific program, social program, satellite meetings and short courses.
